4004#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_MASK (0x400U)
4005#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_SHIFT (10U)
4006#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_MASK)
4007#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSVER2ENA_SHIFT)
4008
4009/*
4010 * TSCTRLSSR (RW)
4011 *
4012 * Timestamp Digital or Binary Rollover Control
4013 * When set, the Timestamp Low register rolls over after 0x3B9A_C9FF value (that is, 1 nanosecond accuracy) and increments the timestamp (High) seconds.
4014 * When reset, the rollover value of sub-second register is 0x7FFF_FFFF.
4015 * The sub-second increment has to be programmed correctly depending on the PTP reference clock frequency and the value of this bit.
4016 */
4017#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_MASK (0x200U)
4018#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_SHIFT (9U)
4019#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_MASK)
4020#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCTRLSSR_SHIFT)
4021
4022/*
4023 * TSENALL (RW)
4024 *
4025 * Enable Timestamp for All Frames
4026 * When set, the timestamp snapshot is enabled for all frames received by the MAC.
4027 */
4028#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_MASK (0x100U)
4029#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_SHIFT (8U)
4030#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_MASK)
4031#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENALL_SHIFT)
4032
4033/*
4034 * TSADDREG (RW)
4035 *
4036 * Addend Reg Update
4037 * When set, the content of the Timestamp Addend register is updated in the PTP block for fine correction. This is cleared when the update is completed.
4038 * This register bit should be zero before setting it.
4039 */
4040#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_MASK (0x20U)
4041#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_SHIFT (5U)
4042#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_MASK)
4043#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSADDREG_SHIFT)
4044
4045/*
4046 * TSTRIG (RW)
4047 *
4048 * Timestamp Interrupt Trigger Enable
4049 * When set, the timestamp interrupt is generated when the System Time becomes greater than the value written in the Target Time register.
4050 * This bit is reset after the generation of the Timestamp Trigger Interrupt.
4051 */
4052#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_MASK (0x10U)
4053#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_SHIFT (4U)
4054#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_MASK)
4055#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSTRIG_SHIFT)
4056
4057/*
4058 * TSUPDT (RW)
4059 *
4060 * Timestamp Update
4061 * When set, the system time is updated (added or subtracted) with the value specified in Register 452 (System Time – Seconds Update Register)
4062 * and Register 453 (System Time – Nanoseconds Update Register). This bit should be read zero before updating it.
4063 * This bit is reset when the update is completed in hardware. The “Timestamp Higher Word” register (if enabled during core configuration) is not updated.
4064 */
4065#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_MASK (0x8U)
4066#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_SHIFT (3U)
4067#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_MASK)
4068#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSUPDT_SHIFT)
4069
4070/*
4071 * TSINIT (RW)
4072 *
4073 * Timestamp Initialize
4074 * When set, the system time is initialized (overwritten) with the value specified in the Register 452 (System Time – Seconds Update Register)
4075 * and Register 453 (System Time – Nanoseconds Update Register). This bit should be read zero before updating it.
4076 * This bit is reset when the initialization is complete.
4077 * The “Timestamp Higher Word” register (if enabled during core configuration) can only be initialized.
4078 */
4079#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_MASK (0x4U)
4080#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_SHIFT (2U)
4081#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_MASK)
4082#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSINIT_SHIFT)
4083
4084/*
4085 * TSCFUPDT (RW)
4086 *
4087 * Timestamp Fine or Coarse Update
4088 * When set, this bit indicates that the system times update should be done using the fine update method. When reset, it indicates the system timestamp update should be done using the Coarse method.
4089 */
4090#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_MASK (0x2U)
4091#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_SHIFT (1U)
4092#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_MASK)
4093#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSCFUPDT_SHIFT)
4094
4095/*
4096 * TSENA (RW)
4097 *
4098 * Timestamp Enable
4099 * When set, the timestamp is added for the transmit and receive frames. When disabled, timestamp is not added for the transmit and receive frames and the Timestamp Generator is also suspended.
4100 * You need to initialize the Timestamp (system time) after enabling this mode. On the receive side, the MAC processes the 1588 frames only if this bit is set.
4101 */
4102#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_MASK (0x1U)
4103#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_SHIFT (0U)
4104#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_MASK)
4105#define ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_MASK) >> ENET_TS_CTRL_TSENA_SHIFT)
4106
4107/* Bitfield definition for register: SUB_SEC_INCR */
4108/*
4109 * SSINC (RW)
4110 *
4111 * Sub-second Increment Value
4112 * The value programmed in this field is accumulated every clock cycle (of clk_ptp_i) with the contents of the sub-second register.
4113 * For example, when PTP clock is 50 MHz (period is 20 ns), you should program 20 (0x14)
4114 * when the System Time- Nanoseconds register has an accuracy of 1 ns [Bit 9 (TSCTRLSSR) is set in Register 448 (Timestamp Control Register)].
4115 * When TSCTRLSSR is clear, the Nanoseconds register has a resolution of ~0.465ns.
4116 * In this case, you should program a value of 43 (0x2B) that is derived by 20ns/0.465.
4117 */
4118#define ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_MASK (0xFFU)
4119#define ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_SHIFT (0U)
4120#define ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_SHIFT) & ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_MASK)
4121#define ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_MASK) >> ENET_SUB_SEC_INCR_SSINC_SHIFT)
4122
4123/* Bitfield definition for register: SYST_SEC */
4124/*
4125 * TSS (RO)
4126 *
4127 * Timestamp Second
4128 * The value in this field indicates the current value in seconds of the System Time maintained by the MAC.
4129 */
4130#define ENET_SYST_SEC_TSS_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4131#define ENET_SYST_SEC_TSS_SHIFT (0U)
4132#define ENET_SYST_SEC_TSS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYST_SEC_TSS_MASK) >> ENET_SYST_SEC_TSS_SHIFT)
4133
4134/* Bitfield definition for register: SYST_NSEC */
4135/*
4136 * TSSS (RO)
4137 *
4138 * Timestamp Sub Seconds
4139 * The value in this field has the sub second representation of time, with an accuracy of 0.46 ns.
4140 * When Bit 9 (TSCTRLSSR) is set in Register 448 (Timestamp Control Register), each bit represents 1 ns and the maximum value is 0x3B9A_C9FF, after which it rolls-over to zero.
4141 */
4142#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_TSSS_MASK (0x7FFFFFFFUL)
4143#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_TSSS_SHIFT (0U)
4144#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_TSSS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYST_NSEC_TSSS_MASK) >> ENET_SYST_NSEC_TSSS_SHIFT)
4145
4146/* Bitfield definition for register: SYST_SEC_UPD */
4147/*
4148 * TSS (RW)
4149 *
4150 * Timestamp Second
4151 * The value in this field indicates the time in seconds to be initialized or added to the system time.
4152 */
4153#define ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4154#define ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_SHIFT (0U)
4155#define ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_SHIFT) & ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_MASK)
4156#define ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_MASK) >> ENET_SYST_SEC_UPD_TSS_SHIFT)
4157
4158/* Bitfield definition for register: SYST_NSEC_UPD */
4159/*
4160 * ADDSUB (RW)
4161 *
4162 * Add or Subtract Time
4163 * When this bit is set, the time value is subtracted with the contents of the update register. When this bit is reset, the time value is added with the contents of the update register.
4164 */
4165#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_MASK (0x80000000UL)
4166#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_SHIFT (31U)
4167#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_SHIFT) & ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_MASK)
4168#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_MASK) >> ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_ADDSUB_SHIFT)
4169
4170/*
4171 * TSSS (RW)
4172 *
4173 * Timestamp Sub Seconds
4174 * The value in this field has the sub second representation of time, with an accuracy of 0.46 ns.
4175 * When Bit 9 (TSCTRLSSR) is set in Register 448 (Timestamp Control Register), each bit represents 1 ns and the programmed value should not exceed 0x3B9A_C9FF.
4176 */
4177#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_MASK (0x7FFFFFFFUL)
4178#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_SHIFT (0U)
4179#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_SHIFT) & ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_MASK)
4180#define ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_MASK) >> ENET_SYST_NSEC_UPD_TSSS_SHIFT)
4181
4182/* Bitfield definition for register: TS_ADDEND */
4183/*
4184 * TSAR (RW)
4185 *
4186 * Timestamp Addend Register
4187 * This field indicates the 32-bit time value to be added to the Accumulator register to achieve time synchronization.
4188 */
4189#define ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4190#define ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_SHIFT (0U)
4191#define ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_SHIFT) & ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_MASK)
4192#define ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_MASK) >> ENET_TS_ADDEND_TSAR_SHIFT)
4193
4194/* Bitfield definition for register: TGTTM_SEC */
4195/*
4196 * TSTR (RW)
4197 *
4198 * Target Time Seconds Register
4199 * This register stores the time in seconds.
4200 * When the timestamp value matches or exceeds both Target Timestamp registers,
4201 * then based on Bits [6:5] of Register 459 (PPS Control Register), the MAC starts or stops the PPS signal output and generates an interrupt (if enabled).
4202 */
4203#define ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4204#define ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_SHIFT (0U)
4205#define ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_SHIFT) & ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_MASK)
4206#define ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_MASK) >> ENET_TGTTM_SEC_TSTR_SHIFT)
4207
4208/* Bitfield definition for register: TGTTM_NSEC */
4209/*
4210 * TRGTBUSY (RW)
4211 *
4212 * Target Time Register Busy
4213 * The MAC sets this bit when the PPSCMD field (Bit [3:0]) in Register 459 (PPS Control Register) is programmed to 010 or 011.
4214 * Programming the PPSCMD field to 010 or 011, instructs the MAC to synchronize the Target Time Registers to the PTP clock domain.
4215 * The MAC clears this bit after synchronizing the Target Time Registers to the PTP clock domain
4216 * The application must not update the Target Time Registers when this bit is read as 1.
4217 * Otherwise, the synchronization of the previous programmed time gets corrupted. This bit is reserved when the Enable Flexible Pulse-Per-Second Output feature is not selected.
4218 */
4219#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_MASK (0x80000000UL)
4220#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_SHIFT (31U)
4221#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_SHIFT) & ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_MASK)
4222#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_MASK) >> ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY_SHIFT)
4223
4224/*
4225 * TTSLO (RW)
4226 *
4227 * Target Timestamp Low Register
4228 * This register stores the time in (signed) nanoseconds.
4229 * When the value of the timestamp matches the both Target Timestamp registers,
4230 * then based on the TRGTMODSEL0 field (Bits [6:5]) in Register 459 (PPS Control Register),
4231 * the MAC starts or stops the PPS signal output and generates an interrupt (if enabled).
4232 * This value should not exceed 0x3B9A_C9FF when Bit 9 (TSCTRLSSR) is set in Register 448 (Timestamp Control Register).
4233 * The actual start or stop time of the PPS signal output may have an error margin up to one unit of sub-second increment value.
4234 */
4235#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_MASK (0x7FFFFFFFUL)
4236#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_SHIFT (0U)
4237#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_SHIFT) & ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_MASK)
4238#define ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_MASK) >> ENET_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSLO_SHIFT)
4239
4240/* Bitfield definition for register: SYSTM_H_SEC */
4241/*
4242 * TSHWR (RW)
4243 *
4244 * Timestamp Higher Word Register
4245 * This field contains the most significant 16-bits of the timestamp seconds value. This register is optional and can be selected using the Enable IEEE 1588 Higher Word Register option during core configuration.
4246 * The register is directly written to initialize the value. This register is incremented when there is an overflow from the 32-bits of the System Time - Seconds register.
4247 */
4248#define ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_MASK (0xFFFFU)
4249#define ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_SHIFT (0U)
4250#define ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_SHIFT) & ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_MASK)
4251#define ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_MASK) >> ENET_SYSTM_H_SEC_TSHWR_SHIFT)
4252
4253/* Bitfield definition for register: TS_STATUS */
4254/*
4255 * ATSNS (RO)
4256 *
4257 * Number of Auxiliary Timestamp Snapshots
4258 * This field indicates the number of Snapshots available in the FIFO. A value equal to the selected depth of FIFO (4, 8, or 16) indicates that the Auxiliary Snapshot FIFO is full.
4259 * These bits are cleared (to 00000) when the Auxiliary snapshot FIFO clear bit is set.
4260 * This bit is valid only if the Add IEEE 1588 Auxiliary Snapshot option is selected during core configuration.
4261 */
4262#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSNS_MASK (0x3E000000UL)
4263#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSNS_SHIFT (25U)
4264#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSNS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSNS_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSNS_SHIFT)
4265
4266/*
4267 * ATSSTM (RO)
4268 *
4269 * Auxiliary Timestamp Snapshot Trigger Missed
4270 * This bit is set when the Auxiliary timestamp snapshot FIFO is full and external trigger was set.
4271 * This indicates that the latest snapshot is not stored in the FIFO. This bit is valid only if the Add IEEE 1588 Auxiliary Snapshot option is selected during core configuration.
4272 */
4273#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTM_MASK (0x1000000UL)
4274#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTM_SHIFT (24U)
4275#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTM_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTM_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTM_SHIFT)
4276
4277/*
4278 * ATSSTN (RO)
4279 *
4280 * Auxiliary Timestamp Snapshot Trigger Identifier
4281 * These bits identify the Auxiliary trigger inputs for which the timestamp available in the Auxiliary Snapshot Register is applicable.
4282 * When more than one bit is set at the same time, it means that corresponding auxiliary triggers were sampled at the same clock.
4283 * These bits are applicable only if the number of Auxiliary snapshots is more than one.
4284 * One bit is assigned for each trigger as shown in the following list:
4285 * - Bit 16: Auxiliary trigger 0
4286 * - Bit 17: Auxiliary trigger 1
4287 * - Bit 18: Auxiliary trigger 2
4288 * - Bit 19: Auxiliary trigger 3
4289 * The software can read this register to find the triggers that are set when the timestamp is taken.
4290 */
4291#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTN_MASK (0xF0000UL)
4292#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTN_SHIFT (16U)
4293#define ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTN_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTN_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_ATSSTN_SHIFT)
4294
4295/*
4296 * TSTRGTERR3 (RO)
4297 *
4298 * Timestamp Target Time Error
4299 * This bit is set when the target time, being programmed in Register 496 and Register 497, is already elapsed. This bit is cleared when read by the application.
4300 */
4301#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR3_MASK (0x200U)
4302#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR3_SHIFT (9U)
4303#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR3_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR3_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR3_SHIFT)
4304
4305/*
4306 * TSTARGT3 (RO)
4307 *
4308 * Timestamp Target Time Reached for Target Time PPS3
4309 * When set, this bit indicates that the value of system time is greater than or equal to the value specified in Register 496 (PPS3 Target Time High Register) and Register 497 (PPS3 Target Time Low Register).
4310 */
4311#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT3_MASK (0x100U)
4312#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT3_SHIFT (8U)
4313#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT3_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT3_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT3_SHIFT)
4314
4315/*
4316 * TSTRGTERR2 (RO)
4317 *
4318 */
4319#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR2_MASK (0x80U)
4320#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR2_SHIFT (7U)
4321#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR2_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR2_SHIFT)
4322
4323/*
4324 * TSTARGT2 (RO)
4325 *
4326 */
4327#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT2_MASK (0x40U)
4328#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT2_SHIFT (6U)
4329#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT2_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT2_SHIFT)
4330
4331/*
4332 * TSTRGTERR1 (RO)
4333 *
4334 */
4335#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR1_MASK (0x20U)
4336#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR1_SHIFT (5U)
4337#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR1_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR1_SHIFT)
4338
4339/*
4340 * TSTARGT1 (RO)
4341 *
4342 */
4343#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT1_MASK (0x10U)
4344#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT1_SHIFT (4U)
4345#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT1_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT1_SHIFT)
4346
4347/*
4348 * TSTRGTERR (RO)
4349 *
4350 */
4351#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR_MASK (0x8U)
4352#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR_SHIFT (3U)
4353#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTRGTERR_SHIFT)
4354
4355/*
4356 * AUXTSTRIG (RO)
4357 *
4358 */
4359#define ENET_TS_STATUS_AUXTSTRIG_MASK (0x4U)
4360#define ENET_TS_STATUS_AUXTSTRIG_SHIFT (2U)
4361#define ENET_TS_STATUS_AUXTSTRIG_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_AUXTSTRIG_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_AUXTSTRIG_SHIFT)
4362
4363/*
4364 * TSTARGT (RO)
4365 *
4366 */
4367#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT_MASK (0x2U)
4368#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT_SHIFT (1U)
4369#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSTARGT_SHIFT)
4370
4371/*
4372 * TSSOVF (RO)
4373 *
4374 */
4375#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSSOVF_MASK (0x1U)
4376#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSSOVF_SHIFT (0U)
4377#define ENET_TS_STATUS_TSSOVF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_TS_STATUS_TSSOVF_MASK) >> ENET_TS_STATUS_TSSOVF_SHIFT)
4378
4379/* Bitfield definition for register: PPS_CTRL */
4380/*
4381 * TRGTMODSEL3 (RW)
4382 *
4383 * Target Time Register Mode for PPS3 Output
4384 * This field indicates the Target Time registers (register 496 and 497) mode for PPS3 output signal. This field is similar to the TRGTMODSEL0 field.
4385 */
4386#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_MASK (0x60000000UL)
4387#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_SHIFT (29U)
4388#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_MASK)
4389#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL3_SHIFT)
4390
4391/*
4392 * PPSCMD3 (WO)
4393 *
4394 * Flexible PPS3 Output Control
4395 * This field controls the flexible PPS3 output (ptp_pps_o[3]) signal. This field is similar to PPSCMD0[2:0] in functionality.
4396 */
4397#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_MASK (0x7000000UL)
4398#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_SHIFT (24U)
4399#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_MASK)
4400#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD3_SHIFT)
4401
4402/*
4403 * TRGTMODSEL2 (RW)
4404 *
4405 * Target Time Register Mode for PPS2 Output
4406 * This field indicates the Target Time registers (register 488 and 489) mode for PPS2 output signal. This field is similar to the TRGTMODSEL0 field.
4407 */
4408#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_MASK (0x600000UL)
4409#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_SHIFT (21U)
4410#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_MASK)
4411#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL2_SHIFT)
4412
4413/*
4414 * PPSCMD2 (WO)
4415 *
4416 * Flexible PPS2 Output Control
4417 * This field controls the flexible PPS2 output (ptp_pps_o[2]) signal. This field is similar to PPSCMD0[2:0] in functionality.
4418 */
4419#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_MASK (0x70000UL)
4420#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_SHIFT (16U)
4421#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_MASK)
4422#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD2_SHIFT)
4423
4424/*
4425 * TRGTMODSEL1 (RW)
4426 *
4427 * Target Time Register Mode for PPS1 Output
4428 * This field indicates the Target Time registers (register 480 and 481) mode for PPS1 output signal. This field is similar to the TRGTMODSEL0 field.
4429 */
4430#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_MASK (0x6000U)
4431#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_SHIFT (13U)
4432#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_MASK)
4433#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL1_SHIFT)
4434
4435/*
4436 * PPSCMD1 (WO)
4437 *
4438 * Flexible PPS1 Output Control
4439 * This field controls the flexible PPS1 output (ptp_pps_o[1]) signal. This field is similar to PPSCMD0[2:0] in functionality.
4440 */
4441#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_MASK (0x700U)
4442#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_SHIFT (8U)
4443#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_MASK)
4444#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCMD1_SHIFT)
4445
4446/*
4447 * TRGTMODSEL0 (RW)
4448 *
4449 * Target Time Register Mode for PPS0 Output
4450 * This field indicates the Target Time registers (register 455 and 456) mode for PPS0 output signal:
4451 * - 00: Indicates that the Target Time registers are programmed only for generating the interrupt event.
4452 * - 01: Reserved
4453 * - 10: Indicates that the Target Time registers are programmed for generating the interrupt event and starting or stopping the generation of the PPS0 output signal.
4454 * - 11: Indicates that the Target Time registers are programmed only for starting or stopping the generation of the PPS0 output signal. No interrupt is asserted.
4455 */
4456#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_MASK (0x60U)
4457#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_SHIFT (5U)
4458#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_MASK)
4459#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_TRGTMODSEL0_SHIFT)
4460
4461/*
4462 * PPSEN0 (RW)
4463 *
4464 * Flexible PPS Output Mode Enable
4465 * When set low, Bits [3:0] function as PPSCTRL (backward compatible). When set high, Bits[3:0] function as PPSCMD.
4466 */
4467#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_MASK (0x10U)
4468#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_SHIFT (4U)
4469#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_MASK)
4470#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSEN0_SHIFT)
4471
4472/*
4473 * PPSCTRLCMD0 (RW/WO)
4474 *
4475 * PPSCTRL0: PPS0 Output Frequency Control
4476 * This field controls the frequency of the PPS0 output (ptp_pps_o[0]) signal.
4477 * The default value of PPSCTRL is 0000, and the PPS output is 1 pulse (of width clk_ptp_i) every second.
4478 * For other values of PPSCTRL, the PPS output becomes a generated clock of following frequencies:
4479 * - 0001: The binary rollover is 2 Hz, and the digital rollover is 1 Hz.
4480 * - 0010: The binary rollover is 4 Hz, and the digital rollover is 2 Hz.
4481 * - 0011: The binary rollover is 8 Hz, and the digital rollover is 4 Hz.
4482 * - 0100: The binary rollover is 16 Hz, and the digital rollover is 8 Hz. - ...
4483 * - 1111: The binary rollover is 32.768 KHz, and the digital rollover is 16.384 KHz.
4484 * Note: In the binary rollover mode, the PPS output (ptp_pps_o) has a duty cycle of 50 percent with these frequencies.
4485 * In the digital rollover mode, the PPS output frequency is an average number.
4486 * The actual clock is of different frequency that gets synchronized every second. For example:
4487 * - When PPSCTRL = 0001, the PPS (1 Hz) has a low period of 537 ms and a high period of 463 ms
4488 * - When PPSCTRL = 0010, the PPS (2 Hz) is a sequence of:
4489 * - One clock of 50 percent duty cycle and 537 ms period
4490 * - Second clock of 463 ms period (268 ms low and 195 ms high)
4491 * - When PPSCTRL = 0011, the PPS (4 Hz) is a sequence of:
4492 * - Three clocks of 50 percent duty cycle and 268 ms period
4493 * - Fourth clock of 195 ms period (134 ms low and 61 ms high)
4494 * --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4495 * PPSCMD0: Flexible PPS0 Output Control
4496 * Programming these bits with a non-zero value instructs the MAC to
4497 * initiate an event. When the command is transferred or synchronized to
4498 * the PTP clock domain, these bits get cleared automatically. The
4499 * Software should ensure that these bits are programmed only when they
4500 * are “all-zero”.
4501 * 0000: No Command
4502 * 0001: START Single Pulse
4503 * This command generates single pulse rising at the start point defined in
4504 * Target Time Registers and of a duration defined
4505 * in the PPS0 Width Register.
4506 * 0010: START Pulse Train
4507 * This command generates the train of pulses rising at the start point
4508 * defined in the Target Time Registers and of a duration defined in the
4509 * PPS0 Width Register and repeated at interval defined in the PPS
4510 * Interval Register. By default, the PPS pulse train is free-running unless
4511 * stopped by ‘STOP Pulse train at time’ or ‘STOP Pulse Train
4512 * immediately’ commands.
4513 * 0011: Cancel START
4514 * This command cancels the START Single Pulse and START Pulse Train
4515 * commands if the system time has not crossed the programmed start
4516 * time.
4517 * 0100: STOP Pulse train at time
4518 * This command stops the train of pulses initiated by the START Pulse
4519 * Train command (PPSCMD = 0010) after the time programmed in the
4520 * Target Time registers elapses.
4521 * 0101: STOP Pulse Train immediately
4522 * This command immediately stops the train of pulses initiated by the
4523 * START Pulse Train command (PPSCMD = 0010).
4524 * 0110: Cancel STOP Pulse train
4525 * This command cancels the STOP pulse train at time command if the
4526 * programmed stop time has not elapsed. The PPS pulse train becomes
4527 * free-running on the successful execution of this command.
4528 * 0111-1111: Reserved
4529 * Note: These bits get cleared automatically
4530 */
4531#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_MASK (0xFU)
4532#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_SHIFT (0U)
4533#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_MASK)
4534#define ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_CTRL_PPSCTRLCMD0_SHIFT)
4535
4536/* Bitfield definition for register: AUX_TS_NSEC */
4537/*
4538 * AUXTSLO (RO)
4539 *
4540 * Contains the lower 31 bits (nano-seconds field) of the auxiliary timestamp.
4541 */
4542#define ENET_AUX_TS_NSEC_AUXTSLO_MASK (0x7FFFFFFFUL)
4543#define ENET_AUX_TS_NSEC_AUXTSLO_SHIFT (0U)
4544#define ENET_AUX_TS_NSEC_AUXTSLO_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_AUX_TS_NSEC_AUXTSLO_MASK) >> ENET_AUX_TS_NSEC_AUXTSLO_SHIFT)
4545
4546/* Bitfield definition for register: AUX_TS_SEC */
4547/*
4548 * AUXTSHI (RO)
4549 *
4550 * Contains the lower 32 bits of the Seconds field of the auxiliary timestamp.
4551 */
4552#define ENET_AUX_TS_SEC_AUXTSHI_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4553#define ENET_AUX_TS_SEC_AUXTSHI_SHIFT (0U)
4554#define ENET_AUX_TS_SEC_AUXTSHI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_AUX_TS_SEC_AUXTSHI_MASK) >> ENET_AUX_TS_SEC_AUXTSHI_SHIFT)
4555
4556/* Bitfield definition for register: PPS0_INTERVAL */
4557/*
4558 * PPSINT (RW)
4559 *
4560 * PPS0 Output Signal Interval
4561 * These bits store the interval between the rising edges of PPS0 signal output in terms of units of sub-second increment value.
4562 * You need to program one value less than the required interval.
4563 * For example, if the PTP reference clock is 50 MHz (period of 20ns),
4564 * and desired interval between rising edges of PPS0 signal output is 100ns
4565 * (that is, five units of sub-second increment value), then you should program value 4 (5 – 1) in this register.
4566 */
4567#define ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4568#define ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT (0U)
4569#define ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK)
4570#define ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK) >> ENET_PPS0_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT)
4571
4572/* Bitfield definition for register: PPS0_WIDTH */
4573/*
4574 * PPSWIDTH (RW)
4575 *
4576 * PPS0 Output Signal Width
4577 * These bits store the width between the rising edge and corresponding falling edge of the PPS0 signal output in terms of units of sub-second increment value.
4578 * You need to program one value less than the required interval.
4579 * For example, if PTP reference clock is 50 MHz (period of 20ns),
4580 * and desired width between the rising and corresponding falling edges of PPS0 signal output is 80ns
4581 * (that is, four units of sub-second increment value), then you should program value 3 (4 – 1) in this register.
4582 */
4583#define ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4584#define ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT (0U)
4585#define ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK)
4586#define ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK) >> ENET_PPS0_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT)
4587
4588/* Bitfield definition for register of struct array PPS: TGTTM_SEC */
4589/*
4590 * TSTRH1 (RW)
4591 *
4592 * PPS1 Target Time Seconds Register
4593 * This register stores the time in seconds.
4594 * When the timestamp value matches or exceeds both Target Timestamp registers,
4595 * then based on Bits [14:13], TRGTMODSEL1, of Register 459 (PPS Control Register),
4596 * the MAC starts or stops the PPS signal output and generates an interrupt (if enabled).
4597 */
4598#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4599#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_SHIFT (0U)
4600#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_MASK)
4601#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_TGTTM_SEC_TSTRH1_SHIFT)
4602
4603/* Bitfield definition for register of struct array PPS: TGTTM_NSEC */
4604/*
4605 * TRGTBUSY1 (RW)
4606 *
4607 * PPS1 Target Time Register Busy
4608 * The MAC sets this bit when the PPSCMD1 field (Bits [10:8]) in Register 459 (PPS Control Register) is programmed to 010 or 011.
4609 * Programming the PPSCMD1 field to 010 or 011 instructs the MAC to synchronize the Target Time Registers to the PTP clock domain.
4610 * The MAC clears this bit after synchronizing the Target Time Registers to the PTP clock domain
4611 * The application must not update the Targeers wht Time Registen this bit is read as 1.
4612 * Otherwise, the synchronization of the previous programmed time gets corrupted.
4613 */
4614#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_MASK (0x80000000UL)
4615#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_SHIFT (31U)
4616#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_MASK)
4617#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TRGTBUSY1_SHIFT)
4618
4619/*
4620 * TTSL1 (RW)
4621 *
4622 * Target Time Low for PPS1 Register
4623 * This register stores the time in (signed) nanoseconds.
4624 * When the value of the timestamp matches the both Target Timestamp registers,
4625 * then based on the TRGTMODSEL1 field (Bits [14:13]) in Register 459 (PPS Control Register),
4626 * the MAC starts or stops the PPS signal output and generates an interrupt (if enabled).
4627 * This value should not exceed 0x3B9A_C9FF when Bit 9 (TSCTRLSSR) is set in Register 448 (Timestamp Control Register).
4628 * The actual start or stop time of the PPS signal output may have an error margin up to one unit of sub-second increment value.
4629 */
4630#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_MASK (0x7FFFFFFFUL)
4631#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_SHIFT (0U)
4632#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_MASK)
4633#define ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_TGTTM_NSEC_TTSL1_SHIFT)
4634
4635/* Bitfield definition for register of struct array PPS: INTERVAL */
4636/*
4637 * PPSINT (RW)
4638 *
4639 * PPS1 Output Signal Interval
4640 * These bits store the interval between the rising edges of PPS1 signal output in terms of units of sub-second increment value.
4641 * You need to program one value less than the required interval. For example, if the PTP reference clock is 50 MHz (period of 20ns),
4642 * and desired interval between rising edges of PPS1 signal output is 100ns (that is, five units of sub-second increment value),
4643 * then you should program value 4 (5 – 1) in this register.
4644 */
4645#define ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4646#define ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT (0U)
4647#define ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK)
4648#define ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_INTERVAL_PPSINT_SHIFT)
4649
4650/* Bitfield definition for register of struct array PPS: WIDTH */
4651/*
4652 * PPSWIDTH (RW)
4653 *
4654 * PPS1 Output Signal Width
4655 * These bits store the width between the rising edge and corresponding falling edge of the PPS1 signal output in terms of units of sub-second increment value.
4656 * You need to program one value less than the required interval. For example,
4657 * if PTP reference clock is 50 MHz (period of 20ns),
4658 * and desired width between the rising and corresponding falling edges of PPS1 signal output is 80ns (that is, four units of sub-second increment value),
4659 * then you should program value 3 (4 – 1) in this register.
4660 */
4661#define ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4662#define ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT (0U)
4663#define ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT) & ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK)
4664#define ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_MASK) >> ENET_PPS_WIDTH_PPSWIDTH_SHIFT)
4665
4666/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_BUS_MODE */
4667/*
4668 * RIB (RW)
4669 *
4670 * Rebuild INCRx Burst
4671 * When this bit is set high and the AHB master gets an EBT (Retry, Split, or Losing bus grant),
4672 * the AHB master interface rebuilds the pending beats of any burst transfer initiated with INCRx.
4673 * The AHB master interface rebuilds the beats with a combination of specified bursts with INCRx and SINGLE.
4674 * By default, the AHB master interface rebuilds pending beats of an EBT with an unspecified (INCR) burst.
4675 */
4676#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_MASK (0x80000000UL)
4677#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_SHIFT (31U)
4678#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_MASK)
4679#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RIB_SHIFT)
4680
4681/*
4682 * PRWG (RW)
4683 *
4684 * Channel Priority
4685 * Weights This field sets the priority weights for Channel 0 during the round-robin arbitration between the DMA channels for the system bus.
4686 * - 00: The priority weight is 1.
4687 * - 01: The priority weight is 2.
4688 * - 10: The priority weight is 3.
4689 * - 11: The priority weight is 4. This field is present in all DWC_gmac configurations except GMAC-AXI when you select the AV feature. Otherwise, this field is reserved and read-only (RO).
4690 */
4691#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_MASK (0x30000000UL)
4692#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_SHIFT (28U)
4693#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_MASK)
4694#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PRWG_SHIFT)
4695
4696/*
4697 * TXPR (RW)
4698 *
4699 * Transmit Priority
4700 * When set, this bit indicates that the transmit DMA has higher priority than the receive DMA during arbitration for the system-side bus. In the GMAC-AXI configuration, this bit is reserved and read-only (RO).
4701 */
4702#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_MASK (0x8000000UL)
4703#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_SHIFT (27U)
4704#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_MASK)
4705#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_TXPR_SHIFT)
4706
4707/*
4708 * MB (RW)
4709 *
4710 * Mixed Burst
4711 * When this bit is set high and the FB bit is low, the AHB master interface starts all bursts of length more than 16 with INCR (undefined burst),
4712 * whereas it reverts to fixed burst transfers (INCRx and SINGLE) for burst length of 16 and less.
4713 */
4714#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_MASK (0x4000000UL)
4715#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_SHIFT (26U)
4716#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_MASK)
4717#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_MB_SHIFT)
4718
4719/*
4720 * AAL (RW)
4721 *
4722 * Address-Aligned Beats
4723 * When this bit is set high and the FB bit is equal to 1,
4724 * the AHB or AXI interface generates all bursts aligned to the start address LS bits. If the FB bit is equal to 0,
4725 * the first burst (accessing the start address of data buffer) is not aligned, but subsequent bursts are aligned to the address.
4726 */
4727#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_MASK (0x2000000UL)
4728#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_SHIFT (25U)
4729#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_MASK)
4730#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_AAL_SHIFT)
4731
4732/*
4733 * PBLX8 (RW)
4734 *
4735 * PBLx8 Mode
4736 * When set high, this bit multiplies the programmed PBL value (Bits [22:17] and Bits[13:8]) eight times.
4737 * Therefore, the DMA transfers the data in 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, and 256 beats depending on the PBL value.
4738 */
4739#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_MASK (0x1000000UL)
4740#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_SHIFT (24U)
4741#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_MASK)
4742#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBLX8_SHIFT)
4743
4744/*
4745 * USP (RW)
4746 *
4747 * Use Separate PBL
4748 * When set high, this bit configures the Rx DMA to use the value configured in Bits [22:17] as PBL.
4749 * The PBL value in Bits [13:8] is applicable only to the Tx DMA operations.
4750 * When reset to low, the PBL value in Bits [13:8] is applicable for both DMA engines.
4751 */
4752#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_MASK (0x800000UL)
4753#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_SHIFT (23U)
4754#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_MASK)
4755#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_USP_SHIFT)
4756
4757/*
4758 * RPBL (RW)
4759 *
4760 * Rx DMA PBL
4761 * This field indicates the maximum number of beats to be transferred in one Rx DMA transaction.
4762 * This is the maximum value that is used in a single block Read or Write.
4763 * The Rx DMA always attempts to burst as specified in the RPBL bit each time it starts a Burst transfer on the host bus.
4764 * You can program RPBL with values of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32. Any other value results in undefined behavior.
4765 * This field is valid and applicable only when USP is set high.
4766 */
4767#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_MASK (0x7E0000UL)
4768#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_SHIFT (17U)
4769#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_MASK)
4770#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_RPBL_SHIFT)
4771
4772/*
4773 * FB (RW)
4774 *
4775 * Fixed Burst
4776 * This bit controls whether the AHB or AXI master interface performs fixed burst transfers or not.
4777 * When set, the AHB interface uses only SINGLE, INCR4, INCR8, or INCR16 during start of the normal burst transfers.
4778 * When reset, the AHB or AXI interface uses SINGLE and INCR burst transfer operations.
4779 */
4780#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_MASK (0x10000UL)
4781#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_SHIFT (16U)
4782#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_MASK)
4783#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_FB_SHIFT)
4784
4785/*
4786 * PR (RW)
4787 *
4788 * Priority Ratio
4789 * These bits control the priority ratio in the weighted round-robin arbitration between the Rx DMA and Tx DMA.
4790 * These bits are valid only when Bit 1 (DA) is reset. The priority ratio is Rx:Tx or Tx:Rx depending on whether Bit 27 (TXPR) is reset or set.
4791 * - 00: The Priority Ratio is 1:1.
4792 * - 01: The Priority Ratio is 2:1.
4793 * - 10: The Priority Ratio is 3:1.
4794 * - 11: The Priority Ratio is 4:1.
4795 */
4796#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_MASK (0xC000U)
4797#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_SHIFT (14U)
4798#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_MASK)
4799#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PR_SHIFT)
4800
4801/*
4802 * PBL (RW)
4803 *
4804 * Programmable Burst Length
4805 * These bits indicate the maximum number of beats to be transferred in one DMA transaction.
4806 * This is the maximum value that is used in a single block Read or Write.
4807 * The DMA always attempts to burst as specified in PBL each time it starts a Burst transfer on the host bus.
4808 * PBL can be programmed with permissible values of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32.
4809 * Any other value results in undefined behavior. When USP is set high, this PBL value is applicable only for Tx DMA transactions.
4810 * If the number of beats to be transferred is more than 32, then perform the following steps: 1. Set the PBLx8 mode. 2. Set the PBL.
4811 */
4812#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_MASK (0x3F00U)
4813#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_SHIFT (8U)
4814#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_MASK)
4815#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_PBL_SHIFT)
4816
4817/*
4818 * ATDS (RW)
4819 *
4820 * Alternate Descriptor Size
4821 * When set, the size of the alternate descriptor (described in “Alternate or Enhanced Descriptors” on page 545) increases to 32 bytes (8 DWORDS).
4822 * This is required when the Advanced Timestamp feature or the IPC Full Checksum Offload Engine (Type 2) is enabled in the receiver.
4823 * The enhanced descriptor is not required if the Advanced Timestamp and IPC Full Checksum Offload Engine (Type 2) features are not enabled.
4824 * In such case, you can use the 16 bytes descriptor to save 4 bytes of memory.
4825 * This bit is present only when you select the Alternate Descriptor feature and any one of the following features during core configuration:
4826 * - Advanced Timestamp feature - IPC Full Checksum Offload Engine (Type 2) feature Otherwise, this bit is reserved and is read-only.
4827 * When reset, the descriptor size reverts back to 4 DWORDs (16 bytes).
4828 */
4829#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_MASK (0x80U)
4830#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_SHIFT (7U)
4831#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_MASK)
4832#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_ATDS_SHIFT)
4833
4834/*
4835 * DSL (RW)
4836 *
4837 * Descriptor Skip Length
4838 * This bit specifies the number of Word, Dword, or Lword (depending on the 32-bit, 64-bit, or 128-bit bus) to skip between two unchained descriptors.
4839 * The address skipping starts from the end of current descriptor to the start of next descriptor.
4840 * When the DSL value is equal to zero, the descriptor table is taken as contiguous by the DMA in Ring mode.
4841 */
4842#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_MASK (0x7CU)
4843#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_SHIFT (2U)
4844#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_MASK)
4845#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DSL_SHIFT)
4846
4847/*
4848 * DA (RW)
4849 *
4850 * DMA Arbitration Scheme
4851 * This bit specifies the arbitration scheme between the transmit and receive paths of Channel 0.
4852 * - 0: Weighted round-robin with Rx:Tx or Tx:Rx The priority between the paths is according to the priority specified in Bits [15:14] (PR) and priority weights specified in Bit 27 (TXPR).
4853 * - 1: Fixed priority The transmit path has priority over receive path when Bit 27 (TXPR) is set. Otherwise, receive path has priority over the transmit path.
4854 */
4855#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_MASK (0x2U)
4856#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_SHIFT (1U)
4857#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_MASK)
4858#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_DA_SHIFT)
4859
4860/*
4861 * SWR (RW)
4862 *
4863 * Software Reset
4864 * When this bit is set, the MAC DMA Controller resets the logic and all internal registers of the MAC.
4865 * It is cleared automatically after the reset operation is complete in all of the DWC_gmac clock domains.
4866 * Before reprogramming any register of the DWC_gmac, you should read a zero (0) value in this bit.
4867 * Note: - The Software reset function is driven only by this bit.
4868 * Bit 0 of Register 64 (Channel 1 Bus Mode Register) or Register 128 (Channel 2 Bus Mode Register) has no impact on the Software reset function.
4869 * - The reset operation is completed only when all resets in all active clock domains are de-asserted.
4870 * Therefore, it is essential that all PHY inputs clocks (applicable for the selected PHY interface) are present for the software reset completion.
4871 * The time to complete the software reset operation depends on the frequency of the slowest active clock.
4872 */
4873#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_MASK (0x1U)
4874#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_SHIFT (0U)
4875#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_MASK)
4876#define ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_BUS_MODE_SWR_SHIFT)
4877
4878/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND */
4879/*
4880 * TPD (RW)
4881 *
4882 * Transmit Poll Demand
4883 * When these bits are written with any value,
4884 * the DMA reads the current descriptor to which the Register 18 (Current Host Transmit Descriptor Register) is pointing.
4885 * If that descriptor is not available (owned by the Host),
4886 * the transmission returns to the Suspend state and Bit 2 (TU) of Register 5 (Status Register) is asserted.
4887 * If the descriptor is available, the transmission resumes.
4888 */
4889#define ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4890#define ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_SHIFT (0U)
4891#define ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_MASK)
4892#define ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_TX_POLL_DEMAND_TPD_SHIFT)
4893
4894/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND */
4895/*
4896 * RPD (RW)
4897 *
4898 * Receive Poll Demand
4899 * When these bits are written with any value,
4900 * the DMA reads the current descriptor to which the Register 19 (Current Host Receive Descriptor Register) is pointing.
4901 * If that descriptor is not available (owned by the Host),
4902 * the reception returns to the Suspended state and Bit 7 (RU) of Register 5 (Status Register) is asserted.
4903 * If the descriptor is available, the Rx DMA returns to the active state.
4904 */
4905#define ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4906#define ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_SHIFT (0U)
4907#define ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_MASK)
4908#define ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_RX_POLL_DEMAND_RPD_SHIFT)
4909
4910/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR */
4911/*
4912 * RDESLA (RW)
4913 *
4914 * Start of Receive List
4915 * This field contains the base address of the first descriptor in the Receive Descriptor list.
4916 * The LSB bits (1:0, 2:0, or 3:0) for 32-bit, 64-bit, or 128-bit bus width are ignored and internally taken as all-zero by the DMA. Therefore, these LSB bits are read-only (RO).
4917 */
4918#define ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4919#define ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_SHIFT (0U)
4920#define ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_MASK)
4921#define ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_RX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_RDESLA_SHIFT)
4922
4923/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR */
4924/*
4925 * TDESLA (RW)
4926 *
4927 * Start of Transmit List
4928 * This field contains the base address of the first descriptor in the Transmit Descriptor list.
4929 * The LSB bits (1:0, 2:0, 3:0) for 32-bit, 64-bit, or 128-bit bus width are ignored and are internally taken as all-zero by the DMA. Therefore, these LSB bits are read-only (RO).
4930 */
4931#define ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_MASK (0xFFFFFFFFUL)
4932#define ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_SHIFT (0U)
4933#define ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_MASK)
4934#define ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_TX_DESC_LIST_ADDR_TDESLA_SHIFT)
4935
4936/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_STATUS */
4937/*
4938 * GLPII (RW)
4939 *
4940 * GLPII: GMAC LPI Interrupt (for Channel 0)
4941 * This bit indicates an interrupt event in the LPI logic of the MAC.
4942 * To reset this bit to 1'b0, the software must read the corresponding registers in the DWC_gmac to get the exact cause of the interrupt and clear its source.
4943 * Note: GLPII status is given only in Channel 0 DMA register and is applicable only when the Energy Efficient Ethernet feature is enabled. Otherwise, this bit is reserved.
4944 * When this bit is high, the interrupt signal from the MAC (sbd_intr_o) is high.
4945 * -or- GTMSI: GMAC TMS Interrupt (for Channel 1 and Channel 2) This bit indicates an interrupt event in the traffic manager and scheduler logic of DWC_gmac.
4946 * To reset this bit, the software must read the corresponding registers (Channel Status Register) to get the exact cause of the interrupt and clear its source.
4947 * Note: GTMSI status is given only in Channel 1 and Channel 2 DMA register when the AV feature is enabled and corresponding additional transmit channels are present.
4948 * Otherwise, this bit is reserved. When this bit is high, the interrupt signal from the MAC (sbd_intr_o) is high.
4949 */
4950#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_MASK (0x40000000UL)
4951#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_SHIFT (30U)
4952#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_MASK)
4953#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLPII_SHIFT)
4954
4955/*
4956 * TTI (RW)
4957 *
4958 * Timestamp Trigger Interrupt
4959 * This bit indicates an interrupt event in the Timestamp Generator block of the DWC_gmac.
4960 * The software must read the corresponding registers in the DWC_gmac to get the exact cause of the interrupt and clear its source to reset this bit to 1'b0.
4961 * When this bit is high, the interrupt signal from the DWC_gmac subsystem (sbd_intr_o) is high.
4962 * This bit is applicable only when the IEEE 1588 Timestamp feature is enabled. Otherwise, this bit is reserved.
4963 */
4964#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_MASK (0x20000000UL)
4965#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_SHIFT (29U)
4966#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_MASK)
4967#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TTI_SHIFT)
4968
4969/*
4970 * GPI (RW)
4971 *
4972 * GMAC PMT Interrupt
4973 * This bit indicates an interrupt event in the PMT module of the DWC_gmac.
4974 * The software must read the PMT Control and Status Register in the MAC to get the exact cause of interrupt and clear its source to reset this bit to 1’b0.
4975 * The interrupt signal from the DWC_gmac subsystem (sbd_intr_o) is high when this bit is high.
4976 * This bit is applicable only when the Power Management feature is enabled.
4977 * Otherwise, this bit is reserved. Note: The GPI and pmt_intr_o interrupts are generated in different clock domains.
4978 */
4979#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_MASK (0x10000000UL)
4980#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_SHIFT (28U)
4981#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_MASK)
4982#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_GPI_SHIFT)
4983
4984/*
4985 * GMI (RW)
4986 *
4987 * GMAC MMC Interrupt
4988 * This bit reflects an interrupt event in the MMC module of the DWC_gmac.
4989 * The software must read the corresponding registers in the DWC_gmac
4990 * to get the exact cause of the interrupt and clear the source of interrupt to make this bit as 1’b0.
4991 * The interrupt signal from the DWC_gmac subsystem (sbd_intr_o) is high when this bit is high.
4992 * This bit is applicable only when the MAC Management Counters (MMC) are enabled. Otherwise, this bit is reserved.
4993 */
4994#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_MASK (0x8000000UL)
4995#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_SHIFT (27U)
4996#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_MASK)
4997#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_GMI_SHIFT)
4998
4999/*
5000 * GLI (RW)
5001 *
5002 * GMAC Line Interface Interrupt
5003 * When set, this bit reflects any of the following interrupt events in the DWC_gmac interfaces (if present and enabled in your configuration):
5004 * - PCS (TBI, RTBI, or SGMII): Link change or auto-negotiation complete event
5005 * - SMII or RGMII: Link change event - General Purpose Input Status (GPIS):
5006 * Any LL or LH event on the gpi_i input ports To identify the exact cause of the interrupt,
5007 * the software must first read Bit 11 and Bits[2:0] of Register 14 (Interrupt Status Register) and then to clear the source of interrupt (which also clears the GLI interrupt),
5008 * read any of the following corresponding registers:
5009 * - PCS (TBI, RTBI, or SGMII): Register 49 (AN Status Register)
5010 * - SMII or RGMII: Register 54 (SGMII/RGMII/SMII Control and Status Register)
5011 * - General Purpose Input (GPI): Register 56 (General Purpose IO Register) The interrupt signal from the DWC_gmac subsystem (sbd_intr_o) is high when this bit is high.
5012 */
5013#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_MASK (0x4000000UL)
5014#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_SHIFT (26U)
5015#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_MASK)
5016#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_GLI_SHIFT)
5017
5018/*
5019 * EB (RW)
5020 *
5021 * Error Bits
5022 * This field indicates the type of error that caused a Bus Error, for example, error response on the AHB or AXI interface.
5023 * This field is valid only when Bit 13 (FBI) is set. This field does not generate an interrupt.
5024 * - 0 0 0: Error during Rx DMA Write Data Transfer
5025 * - 0 1 1: Error during Tx DMA Read Data Transfer
5026 * - 1 0 0: Error during Rx DMA Descriptor Write Access
5027 * - 1 0 1: Error during Tx DMA Descriptor Write Access
5028 * - 1 1 0: Error during Rx DMA Descriptor Read Access
5029 * - 1 1 1: Error during Tx DMA Descriptor Read Access Note: 001 and 010 are reserved.
5030 */
5031#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_MASK (0x3800000UL)
5032#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_SHIFT (23U)
5033#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_MASK)
5034#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_EB_SHIFT)
5035
5036/*
5037 * TS (RW)
5038 *
5039 * Transmit Process State
5040 * This field indicates the Transmit DMA FSM state. This field does not generate an interrupt.
5041 * - 3’b000: Stopped; Reset or Stop Transmit Command issued
5042 * - 3’b001: Running; Fetching Transmit Transfer Descriptor
5043 * - 3’b010: Running; Waiting for status
5044 * - 3’b011: Running; Reading Data from host memory buffer and queuing it to transmit buffer (Tx FIFO)
5045 * - 3’b100: TIME_STAMP write state
5046 * - 3’b101: Reserved for future use
5047 * - 3’b110: Suspended; Transmit Descriptor Unavailable or Transmit Buffer Underflow
5048 * - 3’b111: Running; Closing Transmit Descriptor
5049 */
5050#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_MASK (0x700000UL)
5051#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_SHIFT (20U)
5052#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_MASK)
5053#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TS_SHIFT)
5054
5055/*
5056 * RS (RW)
5057 *
5058 * Receive Process State
5059 * This field indicates the Receive DMA FSM state. This field does not generate an interrupt.
5060 * - 3’b000: Stopped: Reset or Stop Receive Command issued
5061 * - 3’b001: Running: Fetching Receive Transfer Descriptor
5062 * - 3’b010: Reserved for future use
5063 * - 3’b011: Running: Waiting for receive packet
5064 * - 3’b100: Suspended: Receive Descriptor Unavailable
5065 * - 3’b101: Running: Closing Receive Descriptor
5066 * - 3’b110: TIME_STAMP write state
5067 * - 3’b111: Running: Transferring the receive packet data from receive buffer to host memory
5068 */
5069#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_MASK (0xE0000UL)
5070#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_SHIFT (17U)
5071#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_MASK)
5072#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_RS_SHIFT)
5073
5074/*
5075 * NIS (RW)
5076 *
5077 * Normal Interrupt Summary
5078 * Normal Interrupt Summary bit value is the logical OR of the following bits when the corresponding interrupt bits are enabled in
5079 * Register 7 (Interrupt Enable Register):
5080 * - Register 5[0]: Transmit Interrupt
5081 * - Register 5[2]: Transmit Buffer Unavailable
5082 * - Register 5[6]: Receive Interrupt
5083 * - Register 5[14]: Early Receive Interrupt Only unmasked bits
5084 * (interrupts for which interrupt enable is set in Register 7) affect the Normal Interrupt Summary bit.
5085 * This is a sticky bit and must be cleared (by writing 1 to this bit) each time a corresponding bit, which causes NIS to be set, is cleared.
5086 */
5087#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_MASK (0x10000UL)
5088#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_SHIFT (16U)
5089#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_MASK)
5090#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_NIS_SHIFT)
5091
5092/*
5093 * AIS (RW)
5094 *
5095 * Abnormal Interrupt Summary
5096 * Abnormal Interrupt Summary bit value is the logical OR of the following
5097 * when the corresponding interrupt bits are enabled in Register 7 (Interrupt Enable Register):
5098 * - Register 5[1]: Transmit Process Stopped
5099 * - Register 5[3]: Transmit Jabber Timeout
5100 * - Register 5[4]: Receive FIFO Overflow
5101 * - Register 5[5]: Transmit Underflow
5102 * - Register 5[7]: Receive Buffer Unavailable
5103 * - Register 5[8]: Receive Process Stopped
5104 * - Register 5[9]: Receive Watchdog Timeout
5105 * - Register 5[10]: Early Transmit Interrupt
5106 * - Register 5[13]: Fatal Bus Error Only unmasked bits affect the Abnormal Interrupt Summary bit.
5107 * This is a sticky bit and must be cleared (by writing 1 to this bit) each time a corresponding bit, which causes AIS to be set, is cleared.
5108 */
5109#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_MASK (0x8000U)
5110#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_SHIFT (15U)
5111#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_MASK)
5112#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_AIS_SHIFT)
5113
5114/*
5115 * ERI (RW)
5116 *
5117 * Early Receive Interrupt
5118 * This bit indicates that the DMA filled the first data buffer of the packet. This bit is cleared when the software writes 1 to this bit or Bit 6 (RI) of this register is set (whichever occurs earlier).
5119 */
5120#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_MASK (0x4000U)
5121#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_SHIFT (14U)
5122#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_MASK)
5123#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_ERI_SHIFT)
5124
5125/*
5126 * FBI (RW)
5127 *
5128 * Fatal Bus Error Interrupt
5129 * This bit indicates that a bus error occurred, as described in Bits [25:23]. When this bit is set, the corresponding DMA engine disables all of its bus accesses.
5130 */
5131#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_MASK (0x2000U)
5132#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_SHIFT (13U)
5133#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_MASK)
5134#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_FBI_SHIFT)
5135
5136/*
5137 * ETI (RW)
5138 *
5139 * Early Transmit Interrupt
5140 * This bit indicates that the frame to be transmitted is fully transferred to the MTL Transmit FIFO.
5141 */
5142#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_MASK (0x400U)
5143#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_SHIFT (10U)
5144#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_MASK)
5145#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_ETI_SHIFT)
5146
5147/*
5148 * RWT (RW)
5149 *
5150 * Receive Watchdog Timeout
5151 * When set, this bit indicates that the Receive Watchdog Timer expired while receiving the current frame and the current frame is truncated after the watchdog timeout.
5152 */
5153#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_MASK (0x200U)
5154#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_SHIFT (9U)
5155#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_MASK)
5156#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_RWT_SHIFT)
5157
5158/*
5159 * RPS (RW)
5160 *
5161 * Receive Process Stopped
5162 * This bit is asserted when the Receive Process enters the Stopped state.
5163 */
5164#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_MASK (0x100U)
5165#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_SHIFT (8U)
5166#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_MASK)
5167#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_RPS_SHIFT)
5168
5169/*
5170 * RU (RW)
5171 *
5172 * Receive Buffer Unavailable
5173 * This bit indicates that the host owns the Next Descriptor in the Receive List and the DMA cannot acquire it.
5174 * The Receive Process is suspended. To resume processing Receive descriptors,
5175 * the host should change the ownership of the descriptor and issue a Receive Poll Demand command.
5176 * If no Receive Poll Demand is issued, the Receive Process resumes when the next recognized incoming frame is received.
5177 * This bit is set only when the previous Receive Descriptor is owned by the DMA.
5178 */
5179#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_MASK (0x80U)
5180#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_SHIFT (7U)
5181#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_MASK)
5182#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_RU_SHIFT)
5183
5184/*
5185 * RI (RW)
5186 *
5187 * Receive Interrupt
5188 * This bit indicates that the frame reception is complete.
5189 * When reception is complete, the Bit 31 of RDES1 (Disable Interrupt on Completion) is reset in the last Descriptor,
5190 * and the specific frame status information is updated in the descriptor.
5191 * The reception remains in the Running state.
5192 */
5193#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_MASK (0x40U)
5194#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_SHIFT (6U)
5195#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_MASK)
5196#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_RI_SHIFT)
5197
5198/*
5199 * UNF (RW)
5200 *
5201 * Transmit Underflow
5202 * This bit indicates that the Transmit Buffer had an Underflow during frame transmission. Transmission is suspended and an Underflow Error TDES0[1] is set.
5203 */
5204#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_MASK (0x20U)
5205#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_SHIFT (5U)
5206#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_MASK)
5207#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_UNF_SHIFT)
5208
5209/*
5210 * OVF (RW)
5211 *
5212 * Receive Overflow
5213 * This bit indicates that the Receive Buffer had an Overflow during frame reception. If the partial frame is transferred to the application, the overflow status is set in RDES0[11].
5214 */
5215#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_MASK (0x10U)
5216#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_SHIFT (4U)
5217#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_MASK)
5218#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_OVF_SHIFT)
5219
5220/*
5221 * TJT (RW)
5222 *
5223 * Transmit Jabber Timeout
5224 * This bit indicates that the Transmit Jabber Timer expired, which happens when the frame size exceeds 2,048 (10,240 bytes when the Jumbo frame is enabled).
5225 * When the Jabber Timeout occurs, the transmission process is aborted and placed in the Stopped state. This causes the Transmit Jabber Timeout TDES0[14] flag to assert.
5226 */
5227#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_MASK (0x8U)
5228#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_SHIFT (3U)
5229#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_MASK)
5230#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TJT_SHIFT)
5231
5232/*
5233 * TU (RW)
5234 *
5235 * Transmit Buffer Unavailable
5236 * This bit indicates that the host owns the Next Descriptor in the Transmit List and the DMA cannot acquire it. Transmission is suspended. Bits[22:20] explain the Transmit Process state transitions.
5237 * To resume processing Transmit descriptors, the host should change the ownership of the descriptor by setting TDES0[31] and then issue a Transmit Poll Demand command.
5238 */
5239#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_MASK (0x4U)
5240#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_SHIFT (2U)
5241#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_MASK)
5242#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TU_SHIFT)
5243
5244/*
5245 * TPS (RW)
5246 *
5247 * Transmit Process Stopped
5248 * This bit is set when the transmission is stopped.
5249 */
5250#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_MASK (0x2U)
5251#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_SHIFT (1U)
5252#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_MASK)
5253#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TPS_SHIFT)
5254
5255/*
5256 * TI (RW)
5257 *
5258 * Transmit Interrupt
5259 * This bit indicates that the frame transmission is complete. When transmission is complete, Bit 31 (OWN) of TDES0 is reset, and the specific frame status information is updated in the descriptor.
5260 */
5261#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_MASK (0x1U)
5262#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_SHIFT (0U)
5263#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_MASK)
5264#define ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_STATUS_TI_SHIFT)
5265
5266/* Bitfield definition for register: DMA_OP_MODE */
5267/*
5268 * DT (RW)
5269 *
5270 * Disable Dropping of TCP/IP Checksum Error Frames
5271 * When this bit is set, the MAC does not drop the frames which only have errors detected by the Receive Checksum Offload engine.
5272 * Such frames do not have any errors (including FCS error) in the Ethernet frame received by the MAC but have errors only in the encapsulated payload.
5273 * When this bit is reset, all error frames are dropped if the FEF bit is reset. If the IPC Full Checksum Offload Engine (Type 2) is disabled, this bit is reserved (RO with value 1'b0).
5274 */
5275#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_MASK (0x10000000UL)
5276#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_SHIFT (28U)
5277#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_MASK)
5278#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DT_SHIFT)
5279
5280/*
5281 * RSF (RW)
5282 *
5283 * Receive Store and Forward
5284 * When this bit is set, the MTL reads a frame from the Rx FIFO only after the complete frame has been written to it, ignoring the RTC bits.
5285 * When this bit is reset, the Rx FIFO operates in the cut-through mode, subject to the threshold specified by the RTC bits.
5286 */
5287#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_MASK (0x2000000UL)
5288#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_SHIFT (25U)
5289#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_MASK)
5290#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RSF_SHIFT)
5291
5292/*
5293 * DFF (RW)
5294 *
5295 * Disable Flushing of Received Frames
5296 * When this bit is set, the Rx DMA does not flush any frames because of the unavailability of receive descriptors or buffers as it does normally when this bit is reset. (See “Receive Process Suspended” on page 83.)
5297 */
5298#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_MASK (0x1000000UL)
5299#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_SHIFT (24U)
5300#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_MASK)
5301#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_DFF_SHIFT)
5302
5303/*
5304 * RFA_2 (RW)
5305 *
5306 * MSB of Threshold for Activating Flow Control
5307 * If the DWC_gmac is configured for an Rx FIFO size of 8 KB or more,
5308 * this bit (when set) provides additional threshold levels for activating the flow control in both half-duplex and full-duplex modes.
5309 * This bit (as Most Significant Bit), along with the RFA (Bits [10:9]), gives the following thresholds for activating flow control:
5310 * - 100: Full minus 5 KB, that is, FULL — 5 KB
5311 * - 101: Full minus 6 KB, that is, FULL — 6 KB
5312 * - 110: Full minus 7 KB, that is, FULL — 7 KB
5313 * - 111: Reserved This bit is reserved (and RO) if the Rx FIFO is 4 KB or less deep.
5314 */
5315#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_MASK (0x800000UL)
5316#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_SHIFT (23U)
5317#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_MASK)
5318#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFA_2_SHIFT)
5319
5320/*
5321 * RFD_2 (RW)
5322 *
5323 * MSB of Threshold for Deactivating Flow Control
5324 * If the DWC_gmac is configured for Rx FIFO size of 8 KB or more,
5325 * this bit (when set) provides additional threshold levels for deactivating the flow control in both half-duplex and full-duplex modes.
5326 * This bit (as Most Significant Bit) along with the RFD (Bits [12:11]) gives the following thresholds for deactivating flow control:
5327 * - 100: Full minus 5 KB, that is, FULL — 5 KB
5328 * - 101: Full minus 6 KB, that is, FULL — 6 KB
5329 * - 110: Full minus 7 KB, that is, FULL — 7 KB
5330 * - 111: Reserved This bit is reserved (and RO) if the Rx FIFO is 4 KB or less deep.
5331 */
5332#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_MASK (0x400000UL)
5333#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_SHIFT (22U)
5334#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_MASK)
5335#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_RFD_2_SHIFT)
5336
5337/*
5338 * TSF (RW)
5339 *
5340 * Transmit Store and Forward
5341 * When this bit is set, transmission starts when a full frame resides in the MTL Transmit FIFO.
5342 * When this bit is set, the TTC values specified in Bits [16:14] are ignored.
5343 * This bit should be changed only when the transmission is stopped.
5344 */
5345#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_MASK (0x200000UL)
5346#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_SHIFT (21U)
5347#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_MASK)
5348#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TSF_SHIFT)
5349
5350/*
5351 * FTF (RW)
5352 *
5353 * Flush Transmit FIFO
5354 * When this bit is set, the transmit FIFO controller logic is reset to its default values and thus all data in the Tx FIFO is lost or flushed.
5355 * This bit is cleared internally when the flushing operation is complete.
5356 * The Operation Mode register should not be written to until this bit is cleared.
5357 * The data which is already accepted by the MAC transmitter is not flushed.
5358 * It is scheduled for transmission and results in underflow and runt frame transmission.
5359 */
5360#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_MASK (0x100000UL)
5361#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_SHIFT (20U)
5362#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_MASK)
5363#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_FTF_SHIFT)
5364
5365/*
5366 * TTC (RW)
5367 *
5368 * Transmit Threshold Control
5369 * These bits control the threshold level of the MTL Transmit FIFO.
5370 * Transmission starts when the frame size within the MTL Transmit FIFO is larger than the threshold.
5371 * In addition, full frames with a length less than the threshold are also transmitted.
5372 * These bits are used only when Bit 21 (TSF) is reset.
5373 * - 000: 64
5374 * - 001: 128
5375 * - 010: 192
5376 * - 011: 256
5377 * - 100: 40
5378 * - 101: 32
5379 * - 110: 24
5380 * - 111: 16
5381 */
5382#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_MASK (0x1C000UL)
5383#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_SHIFT (14U)
5384#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_SET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) << ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_SHIFT) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_MASK)
5385#define ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_GET(x) (((uint32_t)(x) & ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_MASK) >> ENET_DMA_OP_MODE_TTC_SHIFT)
5386
5387/*
5388 * ST (RW)
5389 *
5390 * Start or Stop Transmission Command
5391 * When this bit is set, transmission is placed in the Running state, and the DMA checks the Transmit List at the current position for a frame to be transmitted.
5392 * Descriptor acquisition is attempted either from the current position in the list,
5393 * which is the Transmit List Base Address set by Register 4 (Transmit Descriptor List Address Register),
5394 * or from the position retained when transmission was stopped previously.
5395 * If the DMA does not own the current descriptor,
5396 * transmission enters the Suspended state and Bit 2 (Transmit Buffer Unavailable) of Register 5 (Status Register) is set.
5397 * The Start Transmission command is effective only when transmission is stopped.
5398 * If the command is issued before setting Register 4 (Transmit Descriptor List Address Register),
5399 * then the DMA behavior is unpredictable. When this bit is reset,
5400 * the transmission process is placed in the Stopped state after completing the transmission of the current frame.
5401 * The Next Descriptor position in the Transmit List is saved,
5402 * and it becomes the current position when transmission is restarted.
